Everything together

Our life is too short, our lifetime cannot exceed much more than 100 years (Steenstrup, Troels, et al., 2017), can create difficulties to imagine a long period of time. There is another difficult to imagine what we cannot see, so it is suggested studying this class slowly.

We live on a planet. When we take a look at the sky during the night, we can see few stars. These facts lead us to different conclusions about the universe in the past millennia, some of them were already discarded with advance of our knowledge, as the Ptolemy geocentrism (Jones, A. Raymond, 2023). Let us see some of the discovers:

  • There is a possibility that works from Maragha observatory could have influence on Nicolau Copérnico's work about heliocentrism, but there is no consensus about this [supposed] influence (Elshaikh, Eman M. ; Goddu, André., 2019, pp. 5, 6).
  • Nicolau Copérnico showed that our planet is not the universe center, and we spin around the Sun (Copernicus, Nicolaus, 1543).
  • Isaac Newton explained the movement of the planets years later (Newton, Isaac, 1686, pp. 401 - 510).
  • It was necessary centuries for Albert Einstein to expand our understanding about gravitation (Einstein Relativity Easy, 2017).
  • Edwin Hubble discovered that the universe is in expansion (Hubble, Edwin, 1929).

Let us do a body exercise, to understand Hubble's discovery:

Practice 1: Expanding like the universe
Cross your arms, reducing the space you are occupying. Now begin opening them slowly until they are completely open.
Hubble observed something like this, but in another scale, to the universe.

The discovery that the universe is in expansion (Bahcall, Neta A., 2015) allowed us to reach another conclusion: in a remote past everything that we can see was in a unique place, the singularity, and after this, there was a great expansion named "Big Bang" theory (Williams, Matt, 2015).

When the universe begins to leave the singularity, we have the Planck epoch, the first period of the universe "life". After this epoch, the first quantities that we can group, the forces, appears (Williams, Matt, 2015).

From the smallest to the biggest

The first moments of the universe had a lot of "agitation", and this fact did not allow the creation of the smallest structures we know nowadays (Williams, Matt, 2015). Three minutes after the universe to leave the singularity, the first nucleus, but the first atoms appear only after thousands of years (NASA, Universe), but our knowledge about them are recent:
  • The idea about atom as something very small, was made by Demócritus (Stewart, Ken, 2023 ; Berryman, Sylvia, 2023).
  • The first scientific work about atoms was published by John Dalton (Dalton, John, 1808 ; Stewart, Ken, 2023)
  • When J. J. Thonsom tested the John Dalton's model, he discovered that there was a subatomic particle with charge, the electron (New, Charlotte, 2022 ; Stewart, Knn, 2023).
  • Ernest Rutherford made experiments proposing a mode that looks alike the solar system with its planets (Rutherford, Ernest, 1911 ; Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia).
  • Niels Bohr proposed a model where atoms have orbitals (Bohr, Niels, 1913 ; Stewart, Ken, 2023)
  • Erwin Schrödinger proposed a quantum model that is still used nowadays (Schrödinger, Erwin, 1926 ; Stewart, Ken, 2023).

Observe that we begin with the idea of something small and indestructible, the atom (Stewart, Ken, 2023), that later was defined by the science, that kept it as something fundamental (Dalton, John, 1808 ; Stewart, Ken, 2023). Years later we discovered that the "smallest" particle had the smallest particles (New, Charlotte, 2022 ; Stewart, Ken, 2023), and we named the new discovery as subatomic particles (Sutton, Christine). Our understanding about what is the smallest element changed on time, but the matter was always made from the smallest to the biggest (NASA, Universe).

Another perception that was changed on time is the atom shape. Take a look at Figure 1, we began with something that cannot be destroyed, we updated for a model where we still had orbits like the solar system. Finally, we arrive in the conclusion that we can determine approximately where electrons can be. More details will be shown in future classes.

Star formation

The star formation did not begin immediately in the universe, it was necessary millions of years to appear the first stars (Yoshii, Yuzuru, et al., 2022), because there was not enough matter to form a giant dust cloud. These clouds, when collapse, make a dense and hot nucleus capable to make union of Hydrogen atoms into Helium atoms, a reaction that is the fuel of stars (NASA, Stars). Not all mass available in dust clouds become star, the remaining material can become planets, comets or continue being a dust (NASA, Stars).

During the star lifetime, small atoms suffer fusion becoming larger atoms, but nor all known atoms are made inside stars. The atom formation has relationship with the star size. The largest element made inside start is the iron (Penovich, Kipp, Smoot et al.). The other elements are made in events known as supernovae (Hajian, Allie et al.).

The star formation creates bigger groups named galaxies (NASA, Universe).

Conclusion

Sample that can be put together, grouped, are appearing in the universe since the first moments after it to leave the singularity. These samples were built since the smallest particles to the giant structures. Next class, we will continue studying the groups that allowed the life to appear.
